head.title: What Did Founders Expect From the Census?; Limits of a Head Count

hedline.hl1: What Did Founders Expect From the Census?; Limits of a Head Count

abstract.p: Keith Bradley letter says 'head count' census system is itself a sampling method (S)

block.p: With the ''head count'' method, the Census Bureau cannot succeed in counting all the people in the United States (''You Fill Up My Census, Even If I Can't Find You,'' Week in Review, Aug. 30).
With the ''head count'' method, the Census Bureau cannot succeed in counting all the people in the United States (''You Fill Up My Census, Even If I Can't Find You,'' Week in Review, Aug. 30).
Therefore the ''head count'' system is itself a sampling method, in which the sample is the portion of the population that actually returns the questionnaire.

The head count vs. sampling debate is really about whether the bureau will ignore the people the census takers miss. The head count method pretends they don't exist, while the statistical sampling method makes very reasonable estimates about them.
The important point is for the Census Bureau to use the most accurate method possible.
